description.narrative:
State of Knowledge Research on Mekong Women and River. This research project will review and publish a state of knowledge in the Mekong region, inclusive of the Salween, of the situation and status for women and rivers, and how women are involved (and/or marginalised) in water governance, river management and water decision making. The research will flag inequities and inconsistencies betweencountries but will also highlight good practice examples from across the six regional countries of the Mekong basin . It will look at trends, and barriers as well as opportunities for women#s involvement within institutions and processes for water and river governance. It should highlight (if possible) positive examples that can be markers for others to improve practice.
While predominantly desk and interview based, the process of investigation will be inclusive and participatory # engaging women leaders, partner organisations and academic researchers. The project builds off work done at the Nargakot Women and Rivers Congress, where the importance ofgenerating and communicating knowledge was highlighted as needing to respect and bring together different forms of knowledge; especially in efforts to influence decision making on rivers and water governance. In particular, a strong focus on bringing together academic knowledge with community knowledge was seen as critical to better inform the political and decision-making domains.
The output of this research will be used as key agenda setting document for a convening of Asia Women and Rivers Congress at the end of March2020 being led by Oxfam. It will provide information and analysis that can then be used to inform programming investments to a moredeliberate support for women in water governance and river management. The intent is that through the research process, we will develop a common set of questions, within a participatory research framework, so that it can be used in other sub-regions and basin contexts. This TOR outlines early thinking on the framework and questions, that will be further developed through the project.

participating-org.narrative: International Rivers (IR) has played a key role in supporting civil society networks to understand hydropower and to be better prepared to fight against bad projects, and advocate for their rivers and livelihoods. IR, along with Oxfam, has been key in supporting the development and operations of the regional Save the Mekong Coalition, and we continue to play a key convening and capacity building role within that network.
International Rivers International Rivers Network dba In
